title: Standing Waves and Stationary Waves - Multiple Choice Questions
subtitle: NIOS Class 12 Physics - Chapter 14: Wave Phenomena

questions.question: Standing or stationary waves are formed when:
options: Single wave travels in one direction
Two waves of same frequency and amplitude travel in opposite directions
Two waves of different frequencies overlap
questions.explanation: Stationary waves are formed by the superposition of two identical waves (same frequency and amplitude) traveling in opposite directions with the same speed along the same line.

questions.question: What is the main difference between traveling waves and standing waves?
options: In traveling waves, wave form moves; in standing waves, it doesn't
questions.explanation: In traveling waves, the wave pattern moves through the medium, transporting energy. In standing waves, the waveform doesn't move forward but oscillates at a fixed location.

questions.question: In a standing wave, points where amplitude is zero are called:
questions.explanation: Nodes are points in a standing wave where the amplitude is zero and particles remain at rest. These occur at fixed positions in the medium.

questions.question: In a standing wave, points where amplitude is maximum are called:
questions.explanation: Antinodes are points in a standing wave where particles oscillate with maximum amplitude. These occur at regular intervals between nodes.

questions.question: The distance between two consecutive nodes in a standing wave is:
questions.explanation: The distance between two consecutive nodes (or consecutive antinodes) is λ/2. The distance between a node and the next antinode is λ/4.

questions.question: The distance between a node and the nearest antinode is:
questions.explanation: Since consecutive nodes are λ/2 apart, and antinodes lie midway between nodes, the distance from a node to the nearest antinode is λ/4.

questions.question: The equation of a stationary wave formed by two waves y₁ = a sin(ωt - kx) and y₂ = a sin(ωt + kx) is:
questions.explanation: Using trigonometric addition: y = y₁ + y₂ = 2a cos(ωt)sin(kx). This represents a standing wave where amplitude varies with position but oscillates uniformly with time.

questions.question: In the stationary wave equation y = A cos(ωt), where A = -2a sin(kx), nodes occur at positions where:
questions.explanation: Since nodes occur where amplitude A = 0, we need sin(kx) = 0, which happens at kx = mπ (where m = 0, 1, 2...), giving x = mλ/2.

questions.question: Antinodes occur in a standing wave at positions where:
questions.explanation: Antinodes occur where |sin(kx)| = 1, which gives maximum amplitude. This occurs at kx = (2m+1)π/2, giving x = (2m+1)λ/4.

questions.question: At nodes in a standing wave, what is the particle velocity?
questions.explanation: At nodes, particles don't move; their displacement is always zero. Therefore, particle velocity is zero at all times.

questions.question: At antinodes in a standing wave, what is the strain (∂y/∂x)?
questions.explanation: At antinodes, the slope of the wave profile is zero because antinodes represent positions of uniform amplitude with no spatial variation. Therefore, strain is zero.

questions.question: What happens to the energy in a standing wave?
options: Surges back and forth; net flow across any point is zero
questions.explanation: In standing waves, energy oscillates between kinetic and potential energy in each segment, but there is no net transport of energy past any fixed point. Energy merely surges back and forth.

questions.question: When a transverse wave traveling along a string reflects from a fixed end, what happens?
options: Crest returns as trough (phase reversal of π)
questions.explanation: Reflection from a denser medium (fixed end) causes a phase change of π. A crest becomes a trough, and vice versa. This is because the fixed end is a node.

questions.question: When a transverse wave traveling along a string reflects from a free end, what happens?
options: Crest returns as crest (no phase change)
questions.explanation: Reflection from a rarer medium (free end) causes no phase change. A crest returns as a crest. The free end is an antinode.

questions.question: In a longitudinal standing wave, what is the relationship between compression regions and particle motion?
options: Compressions occur where particles have maximum velocity
Compressions occur at displacement nodes (antinodes in pressure)
questions.explanation: In longitudinal waves, pressure antinodes (maximum pressure change) correspond to displacement nodes, and pressure nodes correspond to displacement antinodes.

questions.question: The time period of oscillation of a stationary wave equals:
options: Sum of time periods of component waves
Difference of time periods of component waves
The time period of the component waves
Half the time period of component waves
questions.explanation: Since stationary waves are formed from two waves of the same frequency, the time period of the resultant standing wave equals the time period of the component waves.

questions.question: A standing wave on a string of length L with both ends fixed must have:
options: A node at one end and antinode at the other
questions.explanation: When both ends of a string are fixed, they act as rigid boundaries and must be nodes. Standing waves on such strings have nodes at both ends.

questions.question: For a string of length L fixed at both ends, the possible wavelengths are:
questions.explanation: For a string fixed at both ends: L = n(λ/2), so λ = 2L/n. The first harmonic has n=1, second has n=2, etc.

questions.question: The strain in a standing wave is:
options: Maximum at antinodes and zero at nodes
Maximum at nodes and zero at antinodes
questions.explanation: Strain (∂y/∂x) is maximum where the waveform has steepest slope, which occurs at nodes where particles transition from positive to negative displacement.

questions.question: In a standing wave, at the same time t, nodes and antinodes are:
options: Nodes at rest, antinodes moving with different velocities
questions.explanation: Nodes remain at rest at all times. Antinodes oscillate with amplitudes determined by position, all reaching maximum displacement simultaneously but with different velocities depending on position.
